item.title: System.Text.StringBuilder
item.description: Constructor StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(); StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(mystring); StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(mystring,capacity); mystring – Initial value of StringBuilder object capacity – Initial size (characters) of buffer. Using StringBuilderMembers decimal bmi = 22.2M; int wt = 168; StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder("My weight is "); sb = sb.Append(wt); // can append number sb = sb.Append(" and my bmi is ").Append(bmi); // my weight is 168 and my bmi is 22.

item.title: A list of open source projects
item.description: I like well designed software. I also like free things, as I’m sure do you. Every now and again these two qualities/properties/attributes intersect and I’ll stumble upon a free, cool piece of software that I reckon may be useful to me (or you) in the future. While there’s a 90% chance that I won’t ever use most of these, here’s a running list of said applications/systems/software nonetheless: Grafana - The open platform for analytics and monitoring https://grafana.

item.title: Using a reverse proxy to provide ssl to a wordpress site hosted on a non-https server
item.description: what’s a reverse proxy? well, in this context, wikipedia has this to say: In computer networks, a reverse proxy is a type of proxy server that retrieves resources on behalf of a client from one or more servers. In the case of secure websites, a web server may not perform SSL encryption itself, but instead offloads the task to a reverse proxy that may be equipped with SSL acceleration hardware.

item.title: Hello Hugo
item.description: Well hello there. This here is how this started: hugo -t black-and-light cd public git add . git commmit -m "initial commit" git push
